questions.text: Which of the following statements about ICD-10 is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ICD-10:

  • Full Name: International Classification of Diseases, 10th Revision.
  • Developed by: World Health Organization (WHO) (Option D ruled out).
  • It provides a Standardized coding for diseases, symptoms, and procedures.

Structure:

Volume 1: Tabular list (disease codes):-

  • Contains the Alphanumeric codes for diseases, injuries, and procedures.
  • Organized into 22 chapters. g., infectious diseases, neoplasms (Option B ruled out).

Volume 2: Instruction manual:-

  • Provides guidelines, rules, and instructions for proper code usage.
  • Includes:
    • Coding conventions (e.g., "Excludes1" vs. "Excludes2").
    • Mortality and morbidity coding rules.
    • Case examples for clarification.

Volume 3: Alphabetical index (for diagnostics).:-

  • Helps locate codes by diagnosis or procedure name

Revision Cycle: Updated every 10-15 years (ICD-11 released in 2019) (Option A ruled out).

Global Use: Mandated for billing/epidemiology in most countries.

Key Takeaways:

  • ICD-10 has 3 volumes (tabular list, manual, index).
  • ICD-11 is the current version, Adopted in 2022.
  • WHO governs ICD revisions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI):

  • It is an indicator used to measure basic quality of life, focusing on health,survival and social well-being.
  • It measures the results of Social, Economical and Political policies.
  • It does not consider Income as an indicator of quality of life.
  • Developed by: Morris David Morris (1979).
  • Components:
    1. Infant Mortality Rate (IMR): Reflects child health and healthcare access (Option A ruled out).
    2. Life Expectancy at Age One: Excludes neonatal mortality to focus on broader survival (Option B ruled out).
    3. Literacy Rate (Option D ruled out).

Comparison with HDI:

  • HDI(Human Development Index) includes: Life expectancy, education (literacy), and GDP.
  • PQLI : Only health/survival metrics.

questions.text: Which of the following is included in the updated definition of HDI?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Human Development Index (HDI):

  • It is defined as a composite index focusing on three basic dimensions of human development:
    • To lead a long and healthy life measured by life expectancy at birth
    • The ability to acquire knowledge, measured by mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling
    • The ability to achieve a decent standard of living, measured by gross national income per capita in PPP US $ (PPP = Purchasing power parity).
  • Purpose:
    • Measures overall development (health, education, income).
    • Used to compare living standards between countries.
  • Developed by: UNDP (1990), updated in 2010.

Updated HDI Components (Post-2010):

  • Health:
    • Life expectancy at birth (Option B ruled out).
  • Education:
    • Mean years of schooling.
    • Expected years of schooling (Option C ruled out).
  • Income:
    • Per capita income (PPP-adjusted) (Option D ruled out).

Key Changes in 2010 Update:

  • Dropped: Adult literacy rate.
  • Added: Education quality/duration metrics.

Range for calculating indices:

questions.text: The value of HDI in India according to latest Human Development report is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • HDI Value of India as per latest Human Development Report, 2023-2024 = 685
  • India ranks 130 out of 191 countries

Reference: https://hdr.undp.org/

questions.text: Human Poverty Index does not include the deprivation of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Human Poverty Index (HPI), developed by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), measures multidimensional poverty, focusing on basic human deprivations rather than just income.
  • Income poverty is measured separately.
  • Income is excluded because HPI focuses on non-monetary deprivations.
  • HPI is calculated in 2 different formats:
    • HPI-1 = Developing countries
    • HPI-2 = Developed countries.

Components of HPI:

Deprivation of Long Life (Option A ruled out):

Probability of not surviving to age 40 (for HPI-1).

Probability of not surviving to age 60 (for HPI-2).

Deprivation of Knowledge (Option B ruled out):

Adult illiteracy rate (lack of basic education) (HPI-1).

% of adults lacking functional literacy skills (HPI-2).

Deprivation of Standard of Living (Option C ruled out):

Composite of:

Lack of access to safe drinking water.

Child malnutrition (underweight children).

Key takeaways:

  • HPI was later replaced by the Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) in 2010, which includes 10 indicators (health, education, living standards).
  • HPI-1 = Developing countries | HPI-2 = Developed countries.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included as a dimension or indicator in the Global Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Global Multidimensional Poverty Index(MPI) is a measure of poverty designed to capture the multiple deprivations that each poor person faces at the same time
  • The Global MPI (developed by UNDP and OPHI) measures poverty using three dimensions:
    • Health: Child mortality, Nutrition
    • Education: Years of schooling, School attendance)
    • Living Standards: Electricity, Sanitation, Drinking water, etc..
  • Occupation is not a parameter in MPI, though it may correlate with income poverty.
  • The MPI reflects both the incidence of multidimensional poverty and its intensity

Value ranges from 0-1:

1 → highest deprivation level

0 → lowest deprivation level

Calculation of MPI:

  • Deprivation Thresholds: A deprivation cutoff is set for each indicator. For example, regarding electricity, a household is considered deprived if it has no electricity.
  • Identifying the Poor: Individuals or households are identified as multidimensionally poor if their deprivation score (sum of the weighted deprivations) is equal to or exceeds a predetermined threshold (e.g., 33.33% or 1/3 of the total weighted indicators).

Deprivation in Indicators:

20-33% → Vulnerable to poverty

> 33% → Poverty

> 50% → Severe Poverty

  • Incidence of Poverty (H): This is the proportion of the population that is multidimensionally poor, calculated by dividing the number of multidimensionally poor people by the total population.
  • Intensity of Poverty (A): This represents the average proportion of weighted deprivations experienced by the multidimensionally poor. It is calculated by summing the deprivation scores of all poor people and dividing by the total number of poor people.

The MPI is the product of the incidence of poverty (H) and the intensity of poverty (A), expressed as MPI = H x A

choices.text: Treatment of contacts of infected individuals

questions.text: Which of the following best defines "surveillance" in public health?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Surveillance is defined by WHO as the ongoing systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health data essential to planning, implementation, and evaluation of public health practice.
  • It is the continuous scrutiny of the factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and other conditions of ill health.
  • Focuses on disease-specific data (human/animal) to guide public health action (e.g., tracking COVID-19 cases).

Incorrect options:

Treatment of contacts (Option B): Part of disease containment, not surveillance.

Prevention of disease (Option C): An outcome of surveillance, not its definition.

Chemoprophylaxis (Option D): A specific intervention, not surveillance.

Key Takeaways:

  • Surveillance = Data collection + Analysis → Guides public health action.
  • Distinguish between surveillance (monitoring) and interventions (e.g., treatment/prevention).

questions.text: "Analysis of routine measurements aimed at detecting changes in the environment" best describes:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Monitoring is defined as ‘the performance and analysis of routine measurements aimed at detecting changes the environment or health status of population'.
  • It is continuous, non-targeted, and focuses on environmental trends rather than disease patterns.

Incorrect options:

Surveillance (Option B): Focuses on disease-specific data (human/animal) to guide public health action (e.g., tracking COVID-19 cases).

Isolation (Option C): A control measure to separate infected individuals, unrelated to data analysis.

Evaluation (Option D): Assesses program effectiveness (e.g., vaccination coverage impact), not routine environmental tracking.

Key Takeaways:

  • Monitoring = Environmental/biological parameter tracking (e.g., pollutant levels).
  • Surveillance = Disease/health event tracking (e.g., influenza outbreaks).

choices.text: Herd immunity from high vaccine coverage

questions.text: A 32-year-old public health officer is designing an intervention program to eliminate measles in a rural community with 95% vaccination coverage. Which of the following factors would contribute most to disease elimination in this population?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Disease elimination requires reducing incidence to zero in a defined area through sustained interventions (WHO).
  • Herd immunity (95% coverage for measles) is crucial as it:
    • Breaks chains of transmission
    • Protects unvaccinated individuals
    • Sustains elimination long-term
  • Isolation/quarantine are outbreak control measures but don't ensure population-level elimination (Option B,C ruled out).

Key Takeaways:

  • Elimination requires population-level immunity > outbreak control.
  • Measles needs 95% vaccine coverage vs. polio (80%) due to higher Ro.

questions.text: A WHO task force is evaluating diseases for global eradication campaigns. All of the following diseases are considered potentially eradicable except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Out of the given options, Tuberculosis is not possible to eradicate.

Eradication requires:

  • No natural reservoir
  • Effective intervention (vaccine/drug)
  • Limited geographic spread

Tuberculosis is not eradicable because:

  • Has animal reservoirs (bovine TB)
  • Latent infections complicate detection
  • No sterilizing vaccine exists

Polio, Measles and Guniea worm are next targets for eradication after smallpox.

Incorrect options:

Guinea worm (Option B): Near eradication (17 cases globally in 2022) - no reservoir, water-based intervention.

Polio (Option C): Type 2/3 eradicated; type 1 persists in 2 countries (WHO 2023).

Measles (Option D): No reservoir; requires 95% vaccine coverage (potential future target).

Key Takeaways:

  • Eradicated diseases: Smallpox, Rinderpest
  • Current targets: Guinea worm, polio
  • TB control relies on elimination, not eradication.

questions.text: Disease eliminated from India are all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diseases eliminated from India:

  • Guineaworm - Feb 2000
  • Leprosy - Dec 2005
  • Yaws - Sep 2006
  • Polio-March 27 2014
  • Neonatal tetanus - May 15, 2015
  • Polio virus 2 - globally certified as eradicated on 20 Sept 2015
  • WHO South-East Asia Region eliminates Maternal and Neonatal Tetanus on 19 May 2016
  • In May 2016, WHO certified India Yaws free.
  • India declared Trachoma Free in December 2017
  • Type 3 wild poliovirus was declared eradicated on 24 October 2019.

Next disease targets for eradication from India:- Kala-azar, Lymphatic Filariasis.

questions.text: In a community health survey, which of the following diseases would most appropriately represent the "tip of the iceberg" phenomenon of disease occurrence?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The "iceberg phenomenon" describes situations where:
    • Reported cases (tip) represent only a small fraction of actual infections
    • Majority of cases remain undiagnosed/subclinical (submerged)
  • Protein energy malnutrition (PEM) displays this phenomena most appropriately as majority cases of PEM remain undiagnosed and undocumented.
  • Malaria, Measles, Rabies are clinically very apparent and do not go undiagnosed.

Key Takeaways:

  • Best "iceberg" examples: PEM, Hepatitis B, Hypertension
  • Poor examples: Measles, Trauma, Advanced cancers, Infections

choices.text: Absolute quarantine is restriction during incubation period
Exclusion of children from schools is modified quarantine
Should not be longer than longest incubation period

questions.text: While reviewing infection control protocols, a medical student encounters several statements about quarantine. All of the following statements about quarantine are correct except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Quarantine has been defined as 'the limitation of freedom of movement of such well persons or domestic animals exposed to communicable disease for a period of time not longer than the longest usual incubation period of the disease, in such manner as to prevent effective contact with those not so exposed'
  • Key Distinction:
    • Quarantine applies to healthy exposed individuals
    • Isolation applies to infected/symptomatic cases (Option A ruled out)
  • Quarantine may comprise
    • Absolute quarantine: Complete movement restriction during entire incubation period (e.g., Ebola contacts)(Option B ruled out)
    • Modified quarantine: Partial restrictions (e.g., school exclusion while allowing home activities)(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A country undergoing rapid industrialization shows a declining trend in infectious diseases but rising rates of cardiovascular diseases and diabetes. This shift in disease patterns is best described as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The theory of Epidemiological transition (Omran's theory) states that "As life expectancy increases, the major causes of death and disability in general shift from communicable, maternal and perinatal causes to chronic, non-communicable ones".

  • Shift from infectious to chronic/man-made diseases
  • Driven by:
    • Improved sanitation/medicine
    • Lifestyle changes (sedentary habits, processed foods)
    • Aging populations
  • 5 Stages of Epidemiological Transition:
    • Pestilence/famine
    • Receding pandemics
    • Degenerative/man-made diseases
    • Delayed degenerative diseases
    • Theoretical - re-emergence/infectious
  • Classic Stage 3 pattern seen in developing nations

Incorrect Options:

Paradoxical transition (Option A): Not a standard epidemiological term

Reversal of transition (Option B): Refers to resurgence of infections (e.g., antibiotic resistance)

Demographic transition (Option D): Population structure changes (birth/death rates), not disease patterns

questions.text: Who is considered as 'The Father of Public Health':
questions.solution:
Explanation:

'Cholera' is known as the father of Public health.

The outbreaks of Cholera in the 19th century had led to the development of groundbreaking advancments in Epidemiology, Sanitation and Modern public health practices, hence given the title as Father of Public health.

Key takeaways:

  • Father of Epidemiology→ Dr John Snow
  • Father of modern medicine→ Hippocrates
  • Father of Indian medicine→ Charaka
  • Father of modern surgery→ Ambroise Pare
  • Father of Indian surgery→ Susrutha
  • Father of Gynaecology→ James Marion Sims
  • Father of Radiology→ WC Roentgen
  • Father of Pathology→ Rudolf Virchow
  • Father of microbiology→ Louis Pasteur
  • Father of antisepsis→ Joseph Lister
  • Father of Physiology→ Claude Bernard
  • Father of Homeopathy→ Samuel Hahnemann
  • Father of Biology→ Aristotle
  • Father of Genetics→ Gregor Mendel
  • Father of modern Anatomy→ Vesalius
  • Father of Psychoanalysis→ Sigmund Freud

questions.text: The Small Pox vaccine was introduced by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Small pox vaccine was introduced by Edward Jenner
  • He coined the term 'Vaccine'
  • It was the first vaccine to be discovered and used on a wide scale
  • It is the first and only disease eradicated so far

Incorrect options:

Paul Ehrlich (Option A): Developed the first effective drug treatment for Syphilis, Arsphenamine (Salvarsan).

Robert Koch (Option B): He was the first to identify causative organism of diseases like Anthrax, TB, Cholera.

Louis Pasteur (Option C): Introduced

  • Germ theory of disease
  • Technique of sterilisation
  • Technique of Pasteurisation
  • Cholera, Anthrax, Rabies vaccines.

questions.text: Which of the following disease is known as "Barometer of Social Welfare"?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tuberculosis is known as the Barometer of social welfare beacuse its incidence and prevelance reflect the overall living conditions of a population.

  • Barometer of Social welfare→ TB
  • Breakbone fever→ Dengue
  • Monkey fever→ KFD
  • 5-day fever→Trench fever
  • 8thday fever→Tetanus neonatorum
  • 100 day cough→Pertussis
  • Slim's disease→HIV/AIDS
  • Black Sickness→Kala-Azar
  • Black Death→Plague

questions.text: All the following are used to measure disability rates in community except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Disability rates are as follows

  1. DALY (Disability adjusted life years)
  2. HALE (Health Adjusted Life Expectancy)
  3. QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years)
  4. Sullivan’s Index/DFLE (Disability Free Life Expectancy)

HPI is Human Poverty Index (HPI) → United Nations development indicator that assessed the level of human deprivation in various countries. It considered factors like life expectancy, education, and basic living standards to measure poverty beyond income alone.

choices.text: Premature death is adjusted for disability
Years lost to premature death and years lived with disability

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DALY
questions.solution:
Explanation:

DALY (Disability adjusted life years)

  • Measure of burden of disease in a defined population and effectiveness of interventions
  • Expresses years lost to premature deaths and years lived with disability adjusted for its severity
  • CALCULATED as YLL+YLD
  • Years of life lost (YLL) and years lost due to disability (YLD)

choices.text: Indian life expectancy used as standard
One DALY means one lost year of life
